title: Little Race Riot
transcript:
<music>

Narrator: Curator, Hendrik Folkerts.

Hendrik Folkerts: Andy Warhol’s series of “Race Riots,” which he made kind of in the early 1960s
through the mid-1960s, was based on a photographic essay by Charles Moore.
Hendrik Folkerts: And Charles Moore kind of depicted three scenes in kind of a nonviolent direct action
by African-American protestors to sort of desegregate Birmingham, Alabama.

<media clip plays>

Martin Luther King: If you will march on with your brothers in Alabama, you will look around and see that
glad day when all of God’s children will be able to cry out, “Free at last, free at last. Thank God, Almighty,
we are free at last.”

Hendrik Folkerts: Something that I was really kind of <clip fades> interested in is reading the caption of
the original photo essay that says, and this is an extremely cynical comment, and a quote, is the
attention-getting jackpot of the provocation. So not only is the sort of protest framed as a provocation,
which it was not, actually, but also, yeah, it seems like this is all they wanted to get to make their point or
something.

Hendrik Folkerts: I think kind of Andy Warhol was extremely interested in the violence of that moment, of
course, because the early ‘60s was also a time of increasing sort of political awareness for him, but he
was also perhaps even more interested in how sort of an image like that lives in a media sort of
landscape. What is the violence being done on these images as they kind of like circulate in very
different environments, as much as this, you know, is happening today in our world? We can look at an
image from very different angles, and an image will be, like, discussed very differently on CNN, ABC, Fox
News or sort of different types of media outlets, if you will.

<music>
